author: By Daniel Levin Becker and Jessica Pettway
title: A Brief History of Bling
description: The story of hip-hop can be told through the stunning and surreal evolution of the jewelry the artists wear.
content: You can’t hear hip-hop jewelry, technically speaking, but that doesn’t mean you don’t know what it sounds like. The word bling, which entered common parlance at the turn of the century, conjures specific sights: small flotillas of twinkling diamonds, gold layered literally to the teeth, watches so gem-encrusted they barely tick. But it also suggests an expansive range of sounds, from the chimes in B.G.’s 1999 anthem “Bling Bling” to the reverberant pomp of Slick Rick, the otherworldly bounce of Missy Elliott, the diced-pineapple opulence of Rick Ross. One beguiling trick of hip-hop production, whether it’s expensive or ersatz, elegant or gaudy, is to convey musically what jewelry signifies visually.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Sanctions Target Foreign Suppliers for Russia’s Military
description: New measures announced Tuesday will affect businesses in Turkey, Dubai and Iran, as well as individuals that Britain says have supplied weaponry or components needed to sustain Russia’s war in Ukraine.
content: Britain moved to curb the supply of military and other vital equipment for the Russian war effort in Ukraine by expanding sanctions on Tuesday to include 22 individuals and companies based outside Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Strange Planet’ Review: An Alien’s Guide to Being Human
description: A new animated series on Apple TV+ examines the banalities of the human experience through an endearingly literal lens.
content: Human beings are strange, though we often don’t like to admit to the arbitrariness of many of our conventions or the contradictions inherent in our behaviors. But the beings of “Strange Planet,” the new Apple TV+ series based on Nathan W. Pyle’s graphic novels and web comics of the same name, embrace the eccentricities of their everyday lives, which look uncannily similar to our own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Judy Holliday’s Old Home in the Village Deserved a Renovation
description: He was hoping to find a turnkey apartment in Manhattan, but how could he resist a place with such a sense of history?
content: In the beginning, Jarrah Al-Buainain wasn’t interested in renovating. When his work as a lawyer brought him to New York from Berkeley, Calif., in 2019, he just wanted to enjoy all that the city had to offer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: Covid Didn’t Take a Summer Vacation
description: Many people don’t want to think about the virus, but an increase in cases means it’s time for a refresher on how to protect yourself and others.
content: You’re not imagining it: Covid-19 cases are on the rise again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas, Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: DeSantis Upends Campaign Leadership as Trump Looms and Urgency Grows
description: Replacing his campaign manager, the Florida governor capped a turbulent period of layoffs, financial worries and a shift in strategy against Donald Trump, the presidential front-runner.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida is shaking up his presidential campaign — again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: ESPN Enters Sports Gambling in $2 Billion Deal With Casino Company
description: ESPN Bet will be operated by Penn Entertainment, which said it was selling its platform’s previous brand, Barstool Sports, back to its founder.
content: ESPN on Tuesday announced a 10-year deal with Penn Entertainment, a casino company, to create an online sports betting brand called ESPN Bet, catapulting the sports entertainment network into the lucrative world of online gambling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Ohio’s One-Issue Election
description: Today’s election could decide the future of abortion rights in Ohio.
content: Early this year, Ohio legislators ended the practice of regularly holding elections in August, pointing to high costs and low turnout. A few months later, the state’s legislature put a measure on the August ballot anyway, one that would make it harder to pass constitutional amendments. It will be the only thing on state ballots when voters head to the polls today.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Video Shows China Blasting Water Cannon at Philippines Coast Guard Boat
description: The clash, in which a Chinese ship blocked 2 Philippine vessels, is the latest in a hotly contested region of the South China Sea.
content: The Philippine Coast Guard has released a video that shows a Chinese Coast Guard vessel firing a water cannon at one of its ships, going public with a new complaint of aggressive behavior from China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Lozada
title: In One Word, Biden and Trump Tell Us Exactly Who They Are
description: The contrast between Biden saying America is “still” a democracy and Trump vowing to make it great “again” is more than a quirk of speechwriting.
content: Presidents are forever linked to their most memorable lines or slogans, phrases that become inseparable from their passage through history. Ronald Reagan proclaimed morning in America. Barack Obama promised America hope and change. Donald Trump pledged to make America great again. Our leaders also utter words they might rather take back — say, about lip-reading or the meaning of “is” — but their go-to lines can capture their message, signal their attitude and even betray their worldview.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Richard Fausset
title: Georgia Grand Jury Likely to Hear Trump Case Next Week
description: The district attorney in Atlanta is expected to take the findings from an election interference investigation to a grand jury, which could issue indictments.
content: The fourth criminal case involving Donald J. Trump is likely to come to a head next week, with the district attorney in Atlanta expected to take the findings from her election interference investigation to a grand jury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Mooj Zadie, Olivia Natt, Michael Simon Johnson, Rachelle Bonja, Lisa Chow, Rachel Quester, Sophia Lanman and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Legal Strategy Behind the Latest Trump Indictment
description: A look at the strengths and weaknesses of the special counsel’s tactics — and at how Donald Trump’s defense might proceed.
content: To win a conviction against former President Donald J. Trump for trying to subvert the results of the 2020 election, Jack Smith, the special counsel, is applying laws in ways that have never been used before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The ‘Never-Again Trumper’ Sham
description: If there’s anything more contemptible than being a villain, it’s being an accomplice.
content: Shortly after last year’s midterms, when Republicans failed to take the Senate and eked out only a thin majority in the House, Paul Ryan gave an interview to ABC’s Jonathan Karl in which he described himself as a “Never-Again Trumper.” It’s worth recalling what Ryan and other Republicans said about Donald Trump the first time he ran to see what a sham this feeble self-designation is likely to become.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: Under a Hellish Ocean Habitat, Bizarre Animals Are Lurking
description: For the first time, scientists observed tubeworms and other complex ocean creatures dwelling beneath hydrothermal vents.
content: Off the western shores of Central and South America, there is a Lovecraftian, lava-licked realm thousands of feet beneath the ocean. There, on the seafloor, volcanically powered exhaust ports known as hydrothermal vents fire off jets of water that reach temperatures of up to 700 degrees Fahrenheit. While the surfaces and peripheries of these vents have long been known to host a diverse mosaic of life, scientists had never known animals to find a home beneath these hellish geysers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gates
title: Give Me a Home Where the Ranchers, Poets and Hippies Roam
description: David James Duncan’s epic novel “Sun House” follows seekers and strivers in a Montana valley.
content: At least give David James Duncan credit for an eclectic and well-nourished sensibility: Not every writer would quote Walt Whitman and Fran Lebowitz in consecutive sentences. His ambitious new novel, “Sun House,” takes its title from an imagined nomadic tribe’s name for Earth, but Duncan is surely alluding to the real-life Delta bluesman Son House, whom one of the characters recalls seeing in performance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Guggenheim Museum Staff Ratifies Union Contract
description: The contract will provide an average salary increase of 11 percent, similar to what other museum workers across the country have obtained during the industry’s multiyear union push.
content: The Guggenheim Museum announced Tuesday that it had reached an agreement with its workers’ union after more than two years of bargaining and that nearly 150 curators, conservators and other employees connected with Local 2110 of the United Auto Workers had ratified their first contract.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: According to TikTok, Americans Are Very, Very Thirsty
description: Drinking water is impossible to come by in Europe — or so goes a complaint on social media. Well-hydrated Europeans have responded with eye rolls from every corner of the continent.
content: Ashley Warren had been in Albania for work for about a week when she realized it: She was really, really thirsty — and nobody else around her seemed to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Upheaval in the Chinese military.
content: For more than a decade, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, has as his signature project brought to heel the once extravagantly corrupt leadership of the People’s Liberation Army. But recent unexpected upheavals in the Chinese military suggest suspicions of graft or other misconduct in the sensitive arm of the military that manages conventional and nuclear missiles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: Divers Hoping to Solve Cold Cases Find 30 Cars in Florida Lake
description: Divers looking for submerged vehicles in an effort to solve missing persons cases discovered over 30 cars over the weekend that they believe may be tied to criminal activity.
content: Volunteer divers looking over the weekend for underwater vehicles in South Florida in an effort to solve missing persons cases found something unexpected: roughly 30 cars submerged under a single lake, according to the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Chang Che
title: Police Investigate Alabama Riverfront Brawl
description: The Montgomery police are seeking the arrest of several people in connection with a fight that broke out over the weekend when a group of white boaters attacked a Black boat captain.
content: The police in Montgomery, Ala., are expected to charge at least three people in connection with a brawl that broke out over the weekend when a group of white boaters attacked a Black boat captain at the city’s popular Riverfront Park. The violent scene, which bystanders captured on video, has stoked memories of the city’s racist history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: DJ Casper, Whose Hit Song ‘Cha-Cha Slide’ Made You Dance, Dies at 58
description: The popular line dance, which gained international fame in the early 2000s, has been a staple at family functions, night clubs and more for more than 20 years.
content: DJ Casper, the creator of the “Cha-Cha Slide,” an infectious song from the early 2000s that sparked an international line-dance craze that rivaled the Electric Slide and drew people to the dance floor at wedding receptions, bar mitzvahs and family cookouts, has died. He was 58.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Watch the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles’ First Fight in ‘Mutant Mayhem’
description: The director Jeff Rowe narrates an animated sequence from his film.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 8, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Aug. 8, 2023.
content: An article on Saturday about the first pill for postpartum depression misspelled the name of a psychiatrist. She is Dr. Ruta Nonacs, not Nunacs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Wednesday Briefing: Few Jobs for Chinese Graduates
description: Also, Afghans try to resist the Taliban and Niger’s coup leaders shun diplomats.
content: This year’s estimated graduating class of 11.6 million students is expected to be the largest ever in China. But the youth unemployment rate has doubled in the last four years, a period of volatility induced by Beijing’s “zero Covid” measures that left companies wary of hiring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Golembiewski
title: First Came ‘the Great Dying,’ Then This Strange Reptile Evolved
description: The creature’s surprising anatomy suggests that rapid and unusual evolution was occurring in the seas after a period of massive extinction.
content: Volcanic eruptions set off a mass extinction 252 million years ago that scientists call “the Great Dying.” The ensuing climate change and acid rain hit life in the oceans hard, with less than 5 percent of marine species making it out alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: The Long, Long Reign of ‘Big Brother’
description: Now entering its 25th season, the reality TV staple has weathered controversy and continues to endure by remaining true to its evergreen formula.
content: When she was first approached to host the CBS reality competition show “Big Brother,” in the summer of 2000, Julie Chen Moonves didn’t know what to think.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas Morino and Joe Coscarelli
title: Tory Lanez Is Sentenced to 10 Years for Shooting Megan Thee Stallion
description: The Canadian rapper, who was found guilty last year, shot her several times in the feet during an argument about their music careers and relationships.
content: A judge in Los Angeles on Tuesday sentenced the Canadian musician Tory Lanez to 10 years in prison for shooting the rapper Megan Thee Stallion during an argument in 2020, the culmination of a case that polarized the music world, filled gossip pages and generated deeper discussion about violence against Black women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: The Toughest ‘Barbie’ Critics Are Barbie Collectors
description: These longtime fans of the doll had high expectations, and concerns, for her big-screen live-action debut.
content: Before going to see “Barbie,” the doll collector Laura Maar had reservations. Based on early images, Maar didn’t like the way the film was portraying Barbie’s pregnant friend, Midge (her personal favorite), or Allan, Ken’s pal who can wear all of his buddy’s clothes. “It just kind of annoyed me the way he was this mealy-mouthed character in the movie, because that’s not him at all.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: What Cuisine Means to Taiwan’s Identity and Its Clash With China
description: Chefs and restaurant owners are using a multiplicity of ingredients and tastes to reflect Taiwan’s roots, shaping a distinct culinary culture.
content: Taiwan is a self-ruling island of 24 million people that is officially known as the Republic of China. Only about a dozen countries recognize it as a nation because China claims it as one of its provinces. Taiwan is called “Chinese Taipei” by international organizations and at the Olympic Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Chivers
title: Soldier Who Called Out Torture in Iraq Is Laid to Rest at Arlington
description: Ian Fishback, who left the Army with the rank of major, was a dissident-in-uniform who died at the age of 42 after entering a dizzying mental health spiral.
content: On a gentle knoll within plain view of the Pentagon he once labored to hold to account, Ian Fishback, an anti-torture whistle-blower during the U.S. occupations of Afghanistan and Iraq, was laid to rest Tuesday with full military honors on the nation’s most hallowed ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euny Hong
title: In Paris, I Get Judged on What I Speak, Not How I Look
description: Learning another language gave me a whole new way of looking at the world. When that language is French and you’re in Paris, it opens other doors as well.
content: I moved from New York back to Paris in the summer of 2020, partly to get away from the spate of anti-Asian assaults that had emerged after the Covid pandemic. The last straw was when I became the victim of a drive-by yelling: Two white guys driving past me stuck their heads out of a car window to shout a racial epithet plus the word “coronavirus.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: WeWork Cites ‘Substantial Doubt’ That It Can Stay in Business
description: The co-working company will seek to raise capital as it searches for a chief executive. Its battered stock plunged further.
content: WeWork, which lost billions of dollars building and operating a global empire of co-working spaces, warned investors on Tuesday that it might not be in business for much longer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caryn Ganz
title: Back in Black and White: It’s the Hives
description: The five-piece punk band from Sweden made a splash in the early 2000s, and their incendiary live shows have never stopped. But new music paused for a decade — until now.
content: Onstage at the cozy Chelsea club Racket in May, Howlin’ Pelle Almqvist had an important announcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed O'Loughlin
title: Ireland Says Goodbye to Sinéad O’Connor
description: In the coastal town of Bray, south of Dublin, the site of Ms. O’Connor’s last Irish home, mourners gathered to pay their respects to the singer.
content: Sinéad O’Connor lived her life poised between tradition and rebellion. Ireland’s farewell to her embraced both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Rebecca Carballo
title: Cleanup Begins After Severe Storms Tear Through Eastern U.S.
description: Air travel was slowly returning to normal, as thousands of homes and businesses remained without power. The powerful storm system moved on to New England, bringing heavy rains and floods.
content: Communities from Tennessee to New York were clearing debris on Tuesday, a day after a wide-ranging storm system that tore through the Eastern United States killed at least two people, left more than a million homes and businesses without power and grounded hundreds of flights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Whether You Call It ‘Skiplagging’ or ‘Hidden-City Travel,’ It’s Contentious
description: Booking a flight with a layover in the city that’s the real destination for the traveler can net big bargains, but airlines prohibit the practice.
content: On the last day of June, American Airlines agents at Gainesville Regional Airport in Florida canceled a North Carolina teenager’s flight after realizing that he had used a booking tactic called “skiplagging” or “hidden-city travel,” forbidden by airlines but used by some travelers to net flight bargains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: A Closer Look at Castor Oil
description: Social media proponents claim it can improve vision, reduce wrinkles, boost hair growth and more. But can it really do all that?
content: According to the Food and Drug Administration, castor oil is approved for just one medicinal use: as a laxative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Justin Simien on Releasing ‘Haunted Mansion’ in the Midst of a Strike
description: The director found himself alone on the promotional tour because his stars couldn’t take part. Still, as a writer, he’s made connections on the picket line.
content: The filmmaker Justin Simien was researching the Haunted Mansion long before he realized it. As a boy, he was a big fan of the Disney attraction. “I literally remember riding this ride over and over again and thinking, ‘God, how do they do this?’” he said. In film school, he realized, “This is all cinema. It was production design — smoke and mirrors and lighting and music and sound.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: 45-Year Sentence for Otoniel, Who Ran a Colombian Drug Cartel
description: Dairo Antonio Úsuga David, the trafficker known as Otoniel, was extradited and pleaded guilty to running a paramilitary group that sent tons of cocaine north.
content: A man described by prosecutors as “the most violent and significant” Colombian drug trafficker since Pablo Escobar was sentenced to 45 years in prison by a judge in Brooklyn federal court on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Butler and Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi
title: Where Did All the Broadway Sets Go?
description: Elaborate theater backdrops are disappearing in favor of bare-bones productions.
content: LAST NOVEMBER, DURING preproduction for his Broadway staging of “A Doll’s House,” the English director Jamie Lloyd and the American playwright Amy Herzog visited Jessica Chastain, the production’s star, at her New York home so the three of them could read Herzog’s adaptation of Henrik Ibsen’s 1879 masterpiece of naturalism out loud. That afternoon, Lloyd recalls, Chastain’s performance felt as if “she was bringing the whole life of Nora into that room,” he says. “I told her, ‘You could just do this whole thing from your armchair.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Swiss Museum Cashier Pockets Over $1 Million in Yearslong Scam
description: A ticket seller at an art museum in Switzerland spent more than a decade skimming cash.
content: For this museum heist, every little bit counted.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Caviar Gets Even More Refined
description: Plus: fashion inspired by fruit, Scandinavian-style glass lamps and more from T’s cultural compendium.
content: These days, it seems that some restaurants will add a dollop of caviar to anything, from fried chicken to hamburgers, practically reducing the once-luxurious treat to a condiment. So it’s perhaps no surprise that chefs are turning their attention to something more rarefied than your everyday osetra: albino caviar, which ranges in color from alabaster to golden, and is the result of uncommon mutations. The most sought after is that of the beluga sturgeon but, says Hermes Gehnen, the founder of N25 Caviar, an international purveyor, “restaurants generally can’t afford it. It’s more for superyachts.” At Les Trois Chevaux in New York, the eggs of the Acipenser ruthenus, a small sturgeon known as the sterlet, are shaped into a quenelle tableside and plated with white asparagus, aerated béchamel and beurre de baratte-basted brioche. The monochromatic presentation allows diners to be “more cognizant of what [they’re] actually tasting,” says the restaurant’s owner, Angie Mar, 41, who describes albino caviar as “supple and velvety.” Rasmus Munk, 32, the chef and co-owner of Alchemist in Copenhagen, is drawn to albino caviar’s “beautiful aroma of butter and creamy texture.” He serves it atop a square of crisp, sourdough-flavored freeze-dried milk born of his collaboration with an M.I.T. researcher on food for space travel. And at the omakase restaurant the Araki in London, the chef Marty Lau slices white cuttlefish and squid into fine ribbons and tops them with a spoonful of golden roe. Although white caviar stock is limited, they aren’t the only pale orbs worth chasing. Snail eggs, which have a mushroomlike flavor, have the same visual appeal despite their earthy taste. Just don’t assume they’ll be a bargain. “Sometimes,” says Munk, “you’ll pay even more money for snail eggs than you do for caviar.” — Lauren Joseph
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Goldsmith
title: The Prosecution of Trump May Have Terrible Consequences
description: It may be justified, but it may come at an enormous cost to the country.
content: It may be satisfying now to see the special counsel Jack Smith indict Donald Trump for his reprehensible and possibly criminal actions in connection with the 2020 presidential election. But the prosecution, which might be justified, reflects a tragic choice that will compound the harms to the nation from Mr. Trump’s many transgressions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Floods, Fires and Torrential Rains Further Bedevil Europe
description: The extreme weather across the continent this summer has destroyed huge amounts of land, forced many to evacuate, and in some cases caused deaths.
content: Floods, fires and heavy rains have landed more blows across Europe this week, with the authorities on the continent scrambling to respond to the extreme weather that has become increasingly common in the past few years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni and Max Bearak
title: Amazon Countries, Led by Brazil, Sign a Rainforest Pact
description: The eight countries that comprise the Amazon River basin agreed on several initiatives to curtail deforestation in the world’s largest and most important rainforest.
content: On Tuesday, the leaders of eight countries that are home to the Amazon River basin agreed to work together to conserve the world’s largest rainforest at a groundbreaking meeting convened by President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: DeSantis Acknowledges Trump’s 2020 Loss, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Teenage Cousin of Uvalde Gunman Arrested Over Threats to a School
description: The teenager, Nathan James Cruz, was arrested after he threatened to “do the same thing” as his cousin, the police said.
content: A 17-year-old cousin of the gunman responsible for the deadly school shooting in Uvalde, Texas, was arrested after his mother reported that he was trying to buy a gun and “do the same thing,” the authorities said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Travis Scott Debuts at No. 1 With the Year’s Biggest Week for Hip-Hop
description: The rapper’s “Utopia,” his first album since his Astroworld Festival in Houston turned tragic in 2021, opens with the equivalent of 496,000 sales in the United States.
content: Almost two years ago, the career of the rap star Travis Scott had seemed in doubt after the catastrophe of his Astroworld Festival in Houston, where 10 people were crushed to death and hundreds more were injured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Michael Boyd, 68, Who Invigorated the Royal Shakespeare Company, Dies
description: He is credited with stabilizing that venerable British troupe while energizing it with ambitious projects, including Broadway’s “Matilda the Musical.”
content: Michael Boyd, who led the Royal Shakespeare Company as artistic director from 2002 to 2012, a decade in which he stabilized the organization while undertaking ambitious projects including a heralded New York residency and the mounting of the un-Shakespearean hit show “Matilda the Musical,” died on Thursday at his home in London. He was 68.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Five Weeknight Tomato Dishes
description: Burst in a coconut-ginger sauce for fish, stir-fried with basil and eggs in fried rice and grated into garlicky pasta.
content: Juicy, acidic and sun-warmed sweet, a perfect summer tomato is a blessing. (A less perfect tomato is fine, if a little dull; a wan out-of-season tomato is to be avoided.) I eat tomatoes every day in August, sometimes at every meal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Martin Walser, 96, Dies; Among Last of Postwar German Literary Titans
description: He won critical and commercial acclaim, but drew censure for comments on the Holocaust and antisemitic tropes in one of his novels.
content: Martin Walser, among the last of a generation of acerbic, socially engaged novelists who dominated the German literary scene after World War II, died on July 26 in Überlingen, Germany, a city on Lake Constance, along the Swiss border. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
title: The Taliban Won but These Afghans Fought On
description: But the Afghan resistance movement is no match for the Taliban’s military might.
content: One man spent his childhood in the foothills of northeastern Afghanistan dreaming of being a soldier for the U.S.-backed government. The other secretly applied to a military academy — against his parents’ wishes — determined to prove himself on the battlefield.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 8 New Songs You Should Hear Now
description: Hear tracks by Wilco, Mitski, maJa and more.
content: Once again, it’s time to get up to speed on new music that’s come out in the past few weeks. Are there any late-breaking candidates for Song of the Summer in today’s playlist? Well, probably not. But maybe your song of the summer is in there, waiting to be discovered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: For ‘Only Murders’ Season 3, Not the Same Old Song and Dance
description: Meryl Streep joined the cast for a season that moved much of the action to Broadway, enlisting a musical theater supergroup to write the songs.
content: Meryl Streep was looking for levity — she was “in despair of the world for so many reasons,” she said, namely the climate crisis. So she reached out to the funniest people she could think of: Steve Martin and Martin Short, whose late-career resurgence as a double act has included a touring stage show, TV specials and their Emmy-winning Hulu comedy, “Only Murders in the Building.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Lisa Friedman
title: Biden to Designate Monument Near Grand Canyon, Preventing Uranium Mining
description: Uranium extraction had already been restricted in the area, which Native tribes consider sacred, but the moratorium was set to expire in 2032. Mr. Biden’s designation will make it permanent.
content: President Biden will designate nearly a million acres of land near the Grand Canyon as a new national monument on Tuesday to protect the area from uranium mining, administration officials confirmed on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Haruka Aoki
title: The Magic of Block Party Season
description: During the dog days of summer in New York, city dwellers gather in the streets to celebrate community and fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim
title: An Oil-Rich Ally Tests Its Relationship With the U.S.
description: The United Arab Emirates, which has translated its wealth into outsize global influence, is diverging from U.S. foreign policy — particularly when it comes to isolating Russia and limiting ties with China.
content: The ruler of the United Arab Emirates, Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed, is a key American ally who counts on the United States to defend his country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Banks Fined $549 Million Over Use of WhatsApp and Other Messaging Apps
description: The penalties add to nearly $2 billion in record-keeping fines last year for the improper policing of employee communications on private messaging services.
content: Federal regulators continued their crackdown against employees of Wall Street firms using private messaging apps to communicate, with 11 brokerage firms and investment advisers agreeing Tuesday to pay $549 million in fines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Bazaar From José Andrés Opens in NoMad
description: The Spanish chef combines dishes from his homeland with Japanese cooking techniques for this NoMad restaurant and more food news.
content: The chef and restaurateur José Andrés’s Bazaar rubric has permitted him to explore many possibilities: tapas, Spanish fare and twists on American dishes like cheesesteak in Washington; a beefier menu at Bazaar Meat in Chicago and Las Vegas; and now in New York, a meeting of Spain and Japan. In addition to cooking for millions in disaster areas and writing several cookbooks, Mr. Andrés has found the time to research the 17th-century voyage of Hasekura Tsunenaga, a noble samurai considered the first Japanese ambassador to Spain and the Americas (he even visited the Vatican). He has inspired Mr. Andrés; Koji Terano, the head chef of research and development; Manuel Echeverri, Mr. Andrés’s culinary director for the various Bazaars; and Victor Rivera, the executive chef in New York, to marry Spanish fare with Japanese preparations. The menu has sections labeled fry/tempura with ham croquetas, chicken karaage and red mullet tempura. Plancha/teppan includes baby squid and crispy socarrat, and josper/robata features short rib and piquillos, honey-miso eggplant and grilled marinated carabinero prawns with Japanese condiments. “It’s a play on the various concepts that are similar,” Mr. Echeverri said. “Raw Bar, Crudos, Sashimi, Same Thing” is a grouping of mostly raw fish preparations. Small bites come under the heading of little starters. The colorful dining room, exuberantly decorated with huge chandeliers and seafaring accents, seats more than 100. On the ground floor, Bazaar Bar serves drinks, including sakes, and small bites. Lázaro Rosa-Violán Studio in Spain designed both areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Love Letters to California
description: A charming set of reader tributes to why the Golden State is home.
content: Surrounded by so much grim news as a reporter, I’m always in search of anything that feels hopeful, or that brings delight into my life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Kanye West Returns to the Stage With Travis Scott
description: The rapper, now known as Ye, had not performed live since a series of antisemitic comments last year led to rebukes in music and fashion.
content: Ye, the rap star formerly known as Kanye West, on Monday made his first concert appearance after a series of antisemitic remarks on social media and in interviews last year, which led to his alienation from the music industry and loss of lucrative fashion deals with Adidas, Gap and Balenciaga.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: China’s Exports Fall Again, Imperiling Its Economic Recovery
description: Shipments to trading partners slid 14.5 percent in July from a year earlier, the biggest decline since February 2020, further pressuring Chinese authorities as they try to rekindle growth.
content: China’s trade numbers dropped in July, according to government data released Tuesday, a sign that the country’s economic rebound was lagging despite efforts by officials in Beijing to revive growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: It’s France and Morocco to finish the round of 16.
description: Many things had to go right for Morocco to make it to the knockout round. The Moroccans were humbled by Germany, 6-0, in their opener but bounced back to defeat both South Korea and Colombia. The South Koreans then did Morocco a huge favor by tying Germany, 1-1, which sealed Morocco’s advancement to the round of 16.
content: Many things had to go right for Morocco to make it to the knockout round. The Moroccans were humbled by Germany, 6-0, in their opener but bounced back to defeat both South Korea and Colombia. The South Koreans then did Morocco a huge favor by tying Germany, 1-1, which sealed Morocco’s advancement to the round of 16.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fu and Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Don’t Be So Picky About a Job, China’s College Graduates Are Told
description: Under pressure from Beijing, Chinese schools have been told to do more to secure jobs for students, who are facing bleak prospects.
content: At this year’s commencement ceremony for the Chongqing Metropolitan College of Science and Technology in southwestern China, the members of the graduating class did not receive the usual lofty message to pursue their dreams. Instead, they were dealt a harsh dose of reality.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Crypto Concept Hopes to Scan 8 Billion Eyes
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, August 8, 2023.
content: “Privacy doesn’t even exist anymore.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and John Liu
title: Taiwan’s Chip Giant Will Build a Plant in Germany
description: TSMC, the world’s largest maker of semiconductors, said it would invest $3.8 billion in a joint project with three European industrial firms.
content: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company said on Tuesday that it would team up with three European technology firms to build a chip-making facility in eastern Germany as part of efforts to further diversify its production locations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Emil T. Lippe
title: Extreme Weather Is Coming. Someone Has to Tell the Chimps.
description: How do you teach 300 chimpanzees to seek safety in a storm? With cowbells, sound machines and a bright orange Frisbee.
content: When Michelle Reininger went to bed on Thursday, June 15, she wasn’t worried about the weather. The last time she checked, the forecast had called for scattered showers. But in the middle of the night, an emergency alert blared on her phone: a severe thunderstorm warning. Winds were expected to reach 80 miles per hour. People should take cover in their homes. “I thought, Is this a joke?” she recalled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Should Bronx Parkland Be Used for a Cricket World Cup Stadium?
description: Mayor Eric Adams wants to build a 34,000-seat temporary stadium in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, but some local cricket players object.
content: Mayor Eric Adams has made no secret of his desire to push New York City as a sports  mecca. He struck a deal in November to build the city’s first professional soccer stadium. He has pitched the region as a site for the 2026 World Cup final.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Regan Stephens
title: Can the Dream of the Four-Day Workweek Start With Restaurants?
description: An emerging group of restaurateurs across the U.S. are choosing work-life balance over their bottom line.
content: On March 15, 2020, the pandemic forced the chef Dominic Piperno to close Hearthside, his then-two-year-old restaurant in Collingswood, N.J. When he reopened it six months later, industrywide staffing shortages meant he could operate only four days a week. During that period, he noticed what seemed like “a better lifestyle for everybody,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Can These Three Much-Loved Musicals Ever Be Truly Revived?
description: “Candide” in an opera house. “Spamalot” and “Rent” cheek by jowl with Shakespeare. But treating them as classics may not be doing them justice.
content: There comes a moment in the afterlife of even the most successful musical when it threatens to become a museum piece. One day, it’s the hot new thing, perhaps even defining its era; next, it’s “The Merry Widow.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edan Lepucki
title: To Have and to Hold, Even if You Turn Into a Literal Shark
description: In her debut novel, Emily Habeck sets up an unusual conundrum for a pair of newlyweds.
content: In Emily Habeck’s beguiling first novel, Lewis and Wren have been married for only a few weeks when Lewis is diagnosed with a Carcharodon carcharias mutation. That explains his nose turning to nothing but cartilage, his intense thirst and appetite, and all those loose molars. By the end of the year, Lewis will transform into a great white shark. When he tells Wren the bad news, she quips, “They say the first year of marriage is the hardest.” The joke has a hard kernel of grief at its center — because, of course, “there would not be another year to measure against this first one.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Weight Loss Drug Cuts Risk of Heart Problems, Maker Says
description: A clinical trial was the first to demonstrate that a new obesity drug could also improve patients’ heart health.
content: A new obesity drug, Wegovy, slashed the risk of serious heart problems by 20 percent in a large trial, the drug’s maker said on Tuesday, a finding that could challenge the perception of weight loss drugs as nothing more than cosmetic medicines and put pressure on insurers to cover them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Why Are Groceries So Expensive?
description: We may shop locally, but on prices you have to think global.
content: Sometimes I talk about inflation with real people — no, not Trump supporters in diners, but people who don’t pore over Bureau of Labor Statistics reports or argue about the relative merits of trimmed mean versus multivariate core trend inflation. And while people don’t necessarily disagree with the proposition that inflation is coming down, they do inevitably bring up the cost of groceries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Steven Erlanger
title: Turbulent Waters: How the Black Sea Became a Hot Spot in the War
description: The Black Sea, a largely overlooked part of the war in Ukraine, is suddenly a cauldron of military and geopolitical tensions. The region is deeply important to Moscow, Ukraine and the West.
content: Russian warships patrol the surface of the Black Sea, launching missiles at Ukrainian towns while creating a de facto blockade, threatening any vessel that might try to breach it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Preston
title: Hush Little Baby, Don’t Say a Word — I Think a Crocodile Heard
description: The semiaquatic reptiles seemed to be roused to action in a study when they heard recordings of crying human and ape infants.
content: Some things need no translation. No matter what language you speak, you can probably recognize a fellow human who is cheering in triumph or swearing in anger. If you are a crocodile, you may recognize the sound of a young animal crying in distress, even if that animal is a totally different species — like, say, a human baby. That sound means you are close to a meal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: More Kids Are Being Exposed to Toxic E-Cigarette Nicotine
description: Here’s how to keep children safe from poisoning.
content: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration is reminding caregivers to store tobacco vaping cartridges safely to prevent children from being poisoned by the liquid inside, noting that e-cigarette exposures have increased sharply over the last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: What’s at Stake in Ohio’s Referendum on Amending the State Constitution
description: The outcome could play a big role in the future of abortion rights in Ohio. But it also raises questions about the power of ordinary citizens over elected politicians.
content: Follow live election results as Ohio votes on Issue 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Curbing Contrails: A Climate Solution in the Skies
description: The wispy condensation from jet airplanes can trap vast amounts of heat in the atmosphere.
content: Slowing down climate change is going to require big fixes, and many small ones, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Pence Qualifies for First G.O.P. Debate, His Campaign Says
description: The former vice president had appeared at risk of missing out on the debate, but he reached the required donor threshold on Monday, his campaign said.
content: Former Vice President Mike Pence on Monday crossed the threshold of 40,000 unique donors required to take part in the first Republican presidential primary debate, his campaign said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shirley Wang
title: What Is IJBOL?
description: A Korean word? A new boy band? This new acronym is replacing LOL and ROFL on social media.
content: First there was LOL (“laugh out loud”), an acronym that first appeared in the 1980s and became the reigning shorthand online for what people found funny. Then came ROFL (“rolling on the floor laughing”), LMAO (“laughing my ass off”) and even nonverbal cues like smiling emojis. Still, most type these terms straight-faced, relegating them to dull punctuation added carelessly to the end of a message. Now, the internet wants to revitalize laughing online with a new term: IJBOL.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaëlle Girbes and Marc Santora
title: A Missile Strikes the Heart of a Ukrainian City — and Then Another
description: Ukrainians say the explosions 37 minutes apart in Pokrovsk, which killed at least nine people and injured 82 others, were a “double tap” intended to kill rescuers responding to the first strike.
content: In the center of a small Ukrainian city, rescuers shrouded in smoke and dust dug through what remained of buildings and bodies on Tuesday, looking for survivors after a pair of missile strikes that President Volodymyr Zelensky said had killed at least nine people and wounded 82 others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Making Summer Special: The Week 7 Winner of Our Summer Reading Contest
description: Aaron Kim, 16, writes about what happened when he put advice from a Well article about staycations to the test.
content: Our annual Summer Reading Contest invites teenagers around the world to tell us what New York Times pieces get their attention and why. This week, the seventh of our 10-week challenge, we received 997 entries. Thank you to everyone who participated, and congratulations to our winner, Aaron Kim, as well as to the runners-up and honorable mentions we honor below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: G.M. Will Add Backup Power Function to Its Electric Vehicles
description: As extreme weather events lead to more power outages, the carmaker said it would equip all its electric vehicles to act as sources of emergency power.
content: General Motors said Tuesday that it planned to equip all its electric cars and trucks with the ability to act as backup power supplies during blackouts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Hoping to Stay in the Shohei Ohtani Business
description: Rather than trade away the game’s best player, Los Angeles tried to get him some help. Now the struggling team has to wait — and hope.
content: The day after slugging his 40th home run of the season — and leaving his pitching duties early because of a cramp in his right middle finger — Shohei Ohtani walked into the Los Angeles Angels clubhouse dressed, as always, in Southern California chic: flip-flops, navy shorts, black T-shirt and a backward black baseball cap.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Portland’s Struggle to Solve Its Homeless Crisis
description: Responses to a story about the challenge to Portland’s “progressive identity.” Also: Trump and the soccer team; justices’ books; patients’ drug choices; student-athletes.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Trying to Process Your Q3? Journal About It.
description: Laura Rubin, a journaling coach, believes there’s a group that is in desperate need of her services: corporate America.
content: On a clear blue Friday in July, a group of 20 people from different professional backgrounds — a sports coach, a television executive, an owner of a public relations company — sat around a table stocked with nuts and fruit in Montauk, N.Y., to learn how to journal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Man Is Wounded in Knife Attack Outside British Museum in London
description: The stabbing outside the popular tourist attraction was not related to terrorism, the police said. A suspect has been arrested.
content: A man was wounded in a stabbing outside the British Museum in central London on Tuesday, the Metropolitan Police said, adding that it was an isolated incident and was not being treated as related to terrorism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: When the Scientific Method Is an Accessory to Murder
description: In Stephen Kearse’s new novel, “Liquid Snakes,” two epidemiologists race to stop a grieving biochemist who has been killing people after the stillborn death of his daughter.
content: Someone sound the alarms, bar the labs and give Dr. Fauci a ring — the scientists have gone mad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: At Bard, a Festival Argues for the Music of Vaughan Williams
description: This year’s Bard Music Festival explores the work and context of a composer who strove to make art “an expression of the whole life of the community.”
content: Perhaps more music festivals should open with a singalong.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Jane Coaston interviews Ben Domenech
description: The Aug. 8, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by Jane Coaston, with Ben Domenech. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: A Conservative on How His Party Has Changed Since 2016
description: Ben Domenech tours the various factions of the Republican Party.
content: The 2024 Republican presidential primary is officially underway, and Donald Trump is dominating the field. But this is a very different contest than it was in 2016. Back then, the Republican Party was the party of foreign policy interventionism, free trade and cutting entitlements, and Trump was the insurgent outsider unafraid to buck the consensus. Today, Trump and his views have become the consensus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Repeat After Her: There Is No Dance Without Dance Education
description: Jody Gottfried Arnhold has a mission (and the means) to cultivate dance education. To her, it is a basic human right — and vital to democracy.
content: At the 92nd Street Y, New York, last month, a diverse bunch of dance teachers from around the country played a game called Slow Land/Fast Land. A strip of blue tape on the floor divided the room in half. Those on one side improvised quick motions while those on the other kept to the opposite speed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danyel  Smith
title: Remembering the Rappers We Lost
description: Biggie. Tupac. DMX. We pay tribute to 63 stars who died too young.
content: Which of you, intending to build a tower, sitteth not down first, and counteth the cost, whether he have sufficient to finish it? — Luke 14:28
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Take a Bath With Me’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: In the supermarket yesterday, a young woman with three babies stopped stock still in front of me. “You look just like my mother,” she said. “A more healthy version, but just like my mother.” I asked if she had lost her mother; the pain was written all over her face. Yes, she had lost her mother to drug abuse. Her father, who raised her, had recently died. A motherless daughter, a stranger, reaching out directly to me — someone who has also spent decades searching for my mother’s face in the crowd. I wanted to hug that girl. Still do. — Lisa Finn
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: The State of Pizza in the Pizza State
description: Wait-worthy pies, a rooftop with apizza and plenty more excellent options in New York.
content: Pizza in New York is a lot like certain calculus problems (or that one scene in “Mean Girls”): The limit does not exist. We will never reach peak pizza, barring some pizza-related disaster. Which brings us to this year’s State of Pizza, my second annual update on the latest pizza goings-on across this big, beautiful, pepperoni-peppered city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Eric Schmitt
title: Hopes for Dialogue Dim in Niger as Junta Clings to Power
description: A leader of the coup in Niger who had been considered a close U.S. ally rejected a request from a visiting U.S. diplomat to release the country’s democratically elected president and bring back constitutional order.
content: The new military leaders of Niger have rebuffed diplomatic efforts by the United States, the United Nations and regional groups to resolve a crisis sparked by a coup in the West African nation, dimming hopes that civilian rule will be restored soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Totally Wipes Out
description: Zachary David Levy states his purpose.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Woman Is Bitten by Shark in First New York City Attack in Years
description: Officials said there had been no reports of shark bites at Rockaway Beach “in recent memory” before Monday’s incident. The woman was in serious but stable condition.
content: A 65-year-old woman was bitten by a shark Monday afternoon at Rockaway Beach, the authorities said, in what appeared to be the first confirmed shark bite in New York City waters in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen
title: Why Is Everyone Suddenly Listening to a Staple of My Angsty Adolescence?
description: In our cynical era, we need cringe music. Enter the Indigo Girls.
content: As one might expect, the soundtrack of the delightful new “Barbie” movie is dominated by the jaunty beats and dulcet tones of some of the reigning queens of female power pop: Dua Lipa, Lizzo and Billie Eilish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Georgia’s Trump case looms
description: Tonight, stream one these William Friedkin films.
content: The fourth criminal case against Donald Trump is likely to intensify next week, when Fani Willis, the district attorney in Fulton County, Ga., is expected to take her election interference case to a grand jury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Besley
title: He Was Tortured During the Troubles. ‘This Is the British Government That’s Doing This.’
description: A Northern Irish man’s relationship with a peregrine falcon reveals a personal history of torture during the Troubles.
content: Before I turned on the camera to interview Jim Auld for this documentary, he cautioned me: “I think it’s impossible to convey the despair that went on in my head.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Goldman Sachs’s C.E.O. Whisperer Takes a Step Back
description: John Rogers, one of the Wall Street firm’s most influential executives, will hand over his chief of staff role to Russell Horwitz, a onetime deputy.
content: The man who has been perhaps the most influential executive inside Goldman Sachs for more than a generation has begun to hand over some of his responsibilities. John Rogers, who over his quarter-century at the Wall Street bank has been known as a board and C.E.O. whisperer, will give his role as chief of staff to Russell Horwitz, his onetime deputy, Andrew and DealBook’s Lauren Hirsch are first to report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: New York Times Revenue Rises 6.3%
description: The company added 180,000 new digital subscribers in the latest quarter, and now has nearly 10 million subscribers in total.
content: The New York Times added 180,000 new digital subscribers in its second quarter, the company said on Tuesday, bringing its total close to 10 million subscribers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Nigeria’s Players Have Enlisted Help to Ensure They Get Paid
description: Some of the overdue pay claims, the team said, go back more than two years.
content: The members of Nigeria’s Women’s World Cup team announced Tuesday that they had restarted a long-running battle with their country’s soccer federation over missing paychecks and bonuses. Some of the overdue pay claims, the team said, go back more than two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: From the Women’s World Cup to Wimbledon, a Victory Everyone Can Share
description: Across sports, female athletes are fighting a battle over what they put on their bodies and how much of those bodies they display.
content: We are in the quarterfinals of that global sporting phenomenon known as the Women’s World Cup. There have been, as usual, shocks and surprises. There have been, less usual, record-breaking crowds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Downey
title: In Ireland’s ‘Forgotten County,’ a Tiny Inn Does It Right
description: Breac House is among the many establishments in County Donegal whose owners rely on regional talent and resources, resulting in a local, yet contemporary, take on accommodation, food and design.
content: The back story of Breac House, a tiny hotel in northwest Ireland’s County Donegal, sounds like a cautionary tale: Two city-slickers, accountants from Dublin, who’d never worked at a hotel or served a scone, decide to open a custom-built, designer property on a remote, windswept peninsula that juts out into the Atlantic Ocean. Cue the wizened locals ready to fleece them, the natural and man-made catastrophes, and you have all the makings of a bad sitcom, with Monocle meets Fawlty Towers as the log line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Thousands of Los Angeles City Workers Strike for One Day
description: Municipal workers walked out on Tuesday to draw attention to widespread understaffing.
content: Thousands of municipal workers in Los Angeles walked off the job for one day on Tuesday to demand that city leaders address widespread staffing shortages that have stretched employees thin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Hopkins
title: Why Do I Get Constipated When I Travel?
description: Our bowels don’t love vacation as much as we do. But there are ways to keep a blockage from slowing down your trip.
content: Q: My bathroom habits are pretty regular at home, but as soon as I leave for a trip, constipation hits. Why am I always backed up on vacation, and what can I do about it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daryln Brewer Hoffstot and Kristian Thacker
title: What You Discover When You Garden at Night
description: Daytime heat forced a writer with a green thumb to change her routine. She found unexpected pleasures.
content: When it’s too hot to garden during the day, what is there to do but garden at night? Neither floppy hat nor gobs of sunscreen will lure me into the glare of a hot and humid, possibly record-breaking, 90-plus-degree day. Or, as our local meteorologist reports: one with a heat index of 103. So instead, I venture out into the garden after dinner, dogs in tow, surveying the raised beds in the coolness of evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Torrent of Water From Alaska Glacier Floods Juneau
description: A river that winds through the state capital of Alaska was overflowing with runoff from the Mendenhall Glacier over the weekend.
content: Residents in Alaska’s capital, Juneau, were urged on Monday to stay away from the Mendenhall River after flooding from a glacier destroyed two buildings and eroded riverbanks in the city over the weekend. Local officials declared a state of emergency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius and Maria Cramer
title: How New York Lost and Regained Control of Union Square
description: The mayhem touched off by a social media personality’s game console giveaway tested the New York Police Department’s response.
content: About 12:30 p.m. Friday, the New York Police Department’s entertainment unit saw that Kai Cenat, a social-media streamer who has more than six million followers, had said that he would be in Manhattan’s Union Square that day, ready to give away free PlayStation 5 consoles and other prizes to fans who showed up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Why Eric Adams Likes to Raise Flags
description: The mayor has attended flag-raising ceremonies for more than 30 countries. It’s all about the art of getting votes.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at why Mayor Eric Adams loves flags and flag-raising ceremonies. We’ll also look at who played a secret role in defending Gov. Andrew Cuomo against claims of sexual misconduct in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Federal Officials May Shut Down Overdose Prevention Centers in Manhattan
description: A nonprofit said it had stopped 1,000 overdoses. Manhattan’s top federal prosecutor said he was eyeing its methods, which are against the law.
content: As street drugs have become ever more powerful and deadly, a small nonprofit in Manhattan dedicated to preventing overdoses has drawn politicians and health officials from around the country searching for possible solutions to the opioid epidemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: By 5-4 Vote, Supreme Court Revives Biden’s Regulation of ‘Ghost Guns’
description: The federal government, citing a rise in violence involving untraced firearms, had asked the justices to step in. The court provisionally allowed the regulation while a challenge moves forward.
content: The Supreme Court on Tuesday temporarily revived the Biden administration’s regulation of “ghost guns” — kits that can be bought online and assembled into untraceable homemade firearms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: bedraggled
description: This word has appeared in 27 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word bedraggled has appeared in 27 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 18 in “Australian Man and His Dog Rescued After Nearly 3 Months at Sea” by Michael Levenson:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Once Rare, Impeachments and Censures Have Become the Norm in Congress
description: Punishments meant to be used only in the most serious circumstances have grown politicized and normalized. New charges against former President Donald J. Trump are likely to spur more recriminations.
content: When the House formally censured Representative Paul Gosar, Republican of Arizona, in November 2021, it was the first time in more than a decade that the punishment had been handed out on the floor. Less than two years elapsed before the next censure — and more attempts are on the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Lisa Friedman and David Iversen
title: With National Monument Designation, Biden Tries to Balance Electoral Realities
description: The president has highlighted his climate actions as a way to spur domestic energy production and create blue-collar jobs, while nodding to environmental activists and tribal leaders.
content: After spending most of his appearance near the Grand Canyon describing how his fifth national monument designation would preserve sagebrush, bighorn sheep and 450 kinds of birds, President Biden said on Tuesday that protecting the land long held sacred by Native American leaders was not just a matter of the environment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Former N.Y.P.D. Commissioner Bernard Kerik Interviewed by Jan. 6 Prosecutors
description: Mr. Kerik, a close ally of the pro-Trump lawyer Rudolph W. Giuliani, was asked about Mr. Trump’s fund-raising efforts and attempts to investigate fraud in the 2020 election.
content: Prosecutors in the office of the special counsel Jack Smith are pressing forward with their investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s attempts to overturn the 2020 election, asking at least one witness this week about fund-raising efforts by Mr. Trump’s political action committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Typhoon Khanun Barrels Over Japan and Heads to South Korea
description: The storm, which battered Okinawa last week, engulfed the southern Japanese island of Kyushu on its way toward the Korean Peninsula.
content: Typhoon Khanun, a tropical cyclone in the Pacific Ocean that battered southern Japan last week, killing at least two people, engulfed the Japanese island of Kyushu on Wednesday, prompting warnings and evacuation orders there and in South Korea, which was next in its path.
source.name: The New York Times
